content:
TITLE: Installing Dependencies with pnpm in CLI
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use pnpm to install project dependencies. It replaces the traditional npm or Yarn commands with the pnpm equivalent.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm install
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using pnpm to add a new dependency
DESCRIPTION: This command uses pnpm to add a new dependency to the project.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/test/__fixtures__/injected-dep-files/should-be-deleted-by-build1.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm add <pkg>
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using getConfig Function from @pnpm/config in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to import and use the getConfig function from @pnpm/config to retrieve pnpm configuration options, which returns a Promise resolving to the configuration object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/config/config/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { getConfig } from '@pnpm/config'

getConfig().then(pnpmConfig => console.log(pnpmConfig))
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Peer Dependency Handling in .npmrc
DESCRIPTION: Covers settings related to peer dependencies. `strict-peer-dependencies` became `true` by default in v14.0.0, enforcing peer dependency resolution. The `auto-install-peers` setting (added v13.10.0) allows automatically installing missing peer dependencies as devDependencies when set to `true`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/config/config/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_19

LANGUAGE: .npmrc
CODE:
```
# Enforce peer dependencies (default since v14.0.0)
strict-peer-dependencies = true

# Automatically install missing peers as devDependencies (added v13.10.0)
auto-install-peers = true
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Package.json Dependency after JSR Install - JSON
DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet shows how package.json is updated after running pnpm add with a JSR package. The dependencies field contains the installed package with its JSR version range (e.g., jsr:^0.1.2). This structure is automatically handled by pnpm and does not require manual edits. The input (pnpm add) results in this output format.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/resolving/default-resolver/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{\n  \"dependencies\": {\n    \"@foo/bar\": \"jsr:^0.1.2\"\n  }\n}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Installing JSR Packages with pnpm
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to install JSR packages using pnpm, including syntax for specifying package names and version ranges.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm add jsr:<pkg_name>
```

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm add jsr:<pkg_name>@<range>
```

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm add jsr:@foo/bar
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining Configurational Dependencies in pnpm - JSON
DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet details the structure for specifying configurational dependencies in the pnpm.configDependencies field of package.json. Configurational dependencies are installed before all other dependencies, cannot themselves have dependencies or lifecycle scripts, and must be defined with an exact version and an integrity checksum. This ensures early and verifiable availability for critical configuration packages. Required: pnpm version supporting configDependencies (referenced by RFC #8 and PR #8915).
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "configDependencies": {
      "my-configs": "1.0.0+sha512-30iZtAPgz+LTIYoeivqYo853f02jBYSd5uGnGpkFV0M3xOt9aN73erkgYAmZU43x4VfqcnLxW9Kpg3R5LC4YYw=="
    }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Outputting Outdated Packages in JSON Format
DESCRIPTION: The outdated command now supports --format=json or --json options to output outdated packages information in JSON format.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_25

LANGUAGE: Bash
CODE:
```
pnpm outdated --format=json
#or
pnpm outdated --json
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Installing Node.js Versions with pnpm env
DESCRIPTION: Commands demonstrating how to use pnpm's environment management to install different Node.js versions, including latest releases, specific versions, and prerelease versions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_54

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm env use -g latest
pnpm env use -g 16.0.0-rc.0
pnpm env use -g nightly
pnpm env use -g nightly/16
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Updating All Dependencies Except Specified Ones
DESCRIPTION: New syntax for updating all dependencies except those specified, using ! in the update command.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_28

LANGUAGE: Bash
CODE:
```
pnpm update !lodash

pnpm update !@babel/*

pnpm update @babel/* !@babel/core
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using resolveStorePath Function from @pnpm/store-path in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to import and use the asynchronous `resolveStorePath` function from the `@pnpm/store-path` package in TypeScript. It takes a project path (e.g., 'F:\\project') and a desired store directory name (e.g., 'pnpm-store') as input and returns the resolved store path, which typically includes a version suffix (e.g., 'F:\\pnpm-store\\2').
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/store/store-path/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
import resolveStorePath from '@pnpm/store-path'

await resolveStorePath('F:\\project', 'pnpm-store')
//> F:\\pnpm-store\\2
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Dependency Patches in package.json
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to patch dependencies using the pnpm.patchedDependencies field in package.json. The configuration specifies the package name, exact version, and relative path to the patch file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/headless/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "patchedDependencies": {
      "eslint@1.0.0": "./patches/eslint@1.0.0.patch"
    }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Example: Installing a Scoped JSR Package with pnpm
DESCRIPTION: Provides a concrete example command for installing a scoped JSR package named `@foo/bar` using the `pnpm add` command with the `jsr:` prefix.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/package-requester/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
pnpm add jsr:@foo/bar
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Allowing Postinstall Scripts for a Dependency Using pnpm add --allow-build - Bash
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to use the pnpm CLI to add a package while explicitly allowing a named dependency (here: 'esbuild') to execute its postinstall scripts. The `--allow-build` flag enables build script execution for the specified dependency both in the current operation and by recording it with `pnpm.onlyBuiltDependencies` in `package.json` for future installs. No additional dependencies are required. Replace 'bundle' and 'esbuild' as needed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm --allow-build=esbuild add bundle

```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Example: Adding a Specific JSR Package with pnpm
DESCRIPTION: Provides a concrete example command for adding the `@foo/bar` package from the JSR registry using pnpm. This demonstrates the practical application of the `jsr:` prefix for installing JSR packages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/resolving/resolver-base/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
pnpm add jsr:@foo/bar
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Resolving a Tarball Dependency with @pnpm/tarball-resolver in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to resolve a tarball URL to a dependency object using the @pnpm/tarball-resolver package in JavaScript. The example imports the default resolver, calls it with a bareSpecifier for the tarball URL, and prints the resolved result as a formatted JSON string. Requires Node.js, @pnpm/tarball-resolver, and uses Promises. The function input is an object with a 'bareSpecifier' string, and the output includes id, normalizedBareSpecifier, resolution object, and resolvedVia type. Limitations include support for URLs only and the requirement that the tarball must be accessible.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/resolving/tarball-resolver/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
'use strict'\nconst resolveFromTarball = require('@pnpm/tarball-resolver').default\n\nresolveFromTarball({bareSpecifier: 'http://registry.npmjs.org/is-array/-/is-array-1.0.1.tgz'})\n  .then(resolveResult => console.log(JSON.stringify(resolveResult, null, 2)))\n  //> {\n  //    "id": "registry.npmjs.org/is-array/-/is-array-1.0.1",\n  //    "normalizedBareSpecifier": "http://registry.npmjs.org/is-array/-/is-array-1.0.1.tgz",\n  //    "resolution": {\n  //      "tarball": "http://registry.npmjs.org/is-array/-/is-array-1.0.1.tgz"\n  //    },\n  //    "resolvedVia": "url"\n  //  }
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Including Workspace Root in Recursive Commands via .npmrc
DESCRIPTION: Adds the `include-workspace-root` setting in v15.5.0. When set to `true`, recursive commands like `run`, `exec`, `add`, and `test` will also operate on the workspace root package.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/config/config/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: .npmrc
CODE:
```
include-workspace-root = true
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Deprecated Version Allowlist
DESCRIPTION: Example configuration to mute specific deprecation warnings in package.json by specifying allowed deprecated versions of packages using wildcards or specific versions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/resolve-dependencies/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "allowedDeprecatedVersions": {
      "request": "*",
      "express": "1"
    }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining Package Overrides in package.json
DESCRIPTION: Example configuration for the "pnpm.overrides" field in package.json that allows overriding dependency versions throughout the project. This feature was introduced in version 5.10.1.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_59

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "overrides": {
      "foo": "^1.0.0",
      "bar@^2.1.0": "3.0.0",
      "qar@1>zoo": "2"
    }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Audit Ignore Rules in PNPM
DESCRIPTION: Example configuration for ignoring specific vulnerabilities in security audits by their GHSA codes using the auditConfig.ignoreGhsas setting
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "auditConfig": {
      "ignoreGhsas": [
        "GHSA-42xw-2xvc-qx8m",
        "GHSA-4w2v-q235-vp99",
        "GHSA-cph5-m8f7-6c5x",
        "GHSA-vh95-rmgr-6w4m"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing Configuration Update Hook in PNPM
DESCRIPTION: Example of using the updateConfig hook in .pnpmfile.cjs to modify PNPM configuration settings. The hook receives the current config and returns a modified version with updated settings. In this case, it changes the nodeLinker setting to 'hoisted'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/hooks/pnpmfile/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
module.exports = {
  hooks: {
    updateConfig: (config) => ({
      ...config,
      nodeLinker: "hoisted",
    }),
  },
};
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using Catalog Protocol in package.json
DESCRIPTION: Example of using the catalog: protocol in package.json to reference default and named catalogs for dependency versions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "dependencies": {
    "chalk": "catalog:",
    "react": "catalog:react16",
    "react-dom": "catalog:react16"
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Setting Node Linker Behavior in .npmrc
DESCRIPTION: The `node-linker` setting (also referred to as `nodeLinker` contextually) configures how the `node_modules` directory is structured. New options `isolated` (default since v15.0.0, uses symlinks) and `hoisted` (creates a flat structure without symlinks) were added in v13.8.0. The default was changed to `isolated` in v15.0.0.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/config/config/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: .npmrc
CODE:
```
# Use isolated (symlinked) node_modules (default from v15.0.0)
node-linker = isolated

# Use hoisted (classic flat) node_modules
node-linker = hoisted
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Package Hoisting Patterns in pnpm
DESCRIPTION: Configuration example showing how to use hoisting patterns in pnpm to control package hoisting behavior. Demonstrates the use of inclusion and exclusion patterns with the '!' prefix for both public-hoist-pattern and hoist-pattern settings.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/config/matcher/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: ini
CODE:
```
public-hoist-pattern[]='*types*'
public-hoist-pattern[]='!@types/react'

hoist-pattern[]='*eslint*'
hoist-pattern[]='!*eslint-plugin*'
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring GitHub Registry Authentication
DESCRIPTION: Example of how to configure npm authentication for a GitHub registry with the owner in the registry path. This configuration allows pnpm to read the auth token correctly.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_48

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
@owner:registry=https://npm.pkg.github.com/owner
//npm.pkg.github.com/:_authToken=<token>
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Registry-Scoped SSL Settings in pnpm (INI)
DESCRIPTION: This configuration snippet demonstrates how to specify registry-specific SSL settings (certificate file, key file, and CA file) within a pnpm configuration file (e.g., .npmrc). This feature, introduced in pnpm v14.0.0, allows different SSL configurations for various registry URLs. Replace the example URL and file paths with actual values.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/core/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: ini
CODE:
```
//registry.mycomp.com/:certfile=server-cert.pem
//registry.mycomp.com/:keyfile=server-key.pem
//registry.mycomp.com/:cafile=client-cert.pem
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Never Built Dependencies
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to specify dependencies that should never be built using the pnpm.neverBuiltDependencies field in package.json. This prevents building of specific packages like fsevents and level.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_58

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "neverBuiltDependencies": ["fsevents", "level"]
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Filtering Workspace Commands for Exclusion
DESCRIPTION: Examples of using the filter option with negation to exclude specific packages or directories from command execution in a workspace. This feature was introduced in version 5.8.0.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_62

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm --filter=!foo test
```

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm --filter=!./lib test
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Declaring Catalogs in pnpm-workspace.yaml
DESCRIPTION: Example of declaring default and named catalogs in the pnpm-workspace.yaml file. Catalogs allow specifying version ranges for dependencies that can be referenced in package.json files.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
# Default catalogs
catalog:
  chalk: ^4.1.2
# Named catalogs
catalogs:
  react16:
    react: ^16.7.0
    react-dom: ^16.7.0
  react17:
    react: ^17.10.0
    react-dom: ^17.10.0
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Allowed Deprecated Versions in package.json
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to configure the pnpm.allowedDeprecatedVersions setting in package.json to ignore specific deprecation messages for packages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/plugin-commands-installation/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: JSON
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "allowedDeprecatedVersions": {
      "request": "*",
      "express": "1"
    }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Initializing Default Reporter in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to initialize and use the default reporter with proper cleanup. Demonstrates importing required dependencies, setting up the reporter with context, and ensuring proper cleanup using try/finally block.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/cli/default-reporter/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { streamParser } from '@pnpm/logger'
import { initDefaultReporter } from '@pnpm/default-reporter'

const stopReporting = initDefaultReporter({
  context: {
    argv: [],
  },
  streamParser,
})

try {
  // calling some pnpm APIs
} finally {
  stopReporting()
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Committing Patches with pnpm patch-commit
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the pnpm patch-commit command to create a patch file from modifications made to a package. This command also updates the package.json file with the new patch reference.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_35

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm patch-commit <path to temp folder>
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing the injected Property with React Dependencies
DESCRIPTION: Configuration showing how to use the injected property to handle a package with React peer dependencies across projects that use different React versions. This creates hard links instead of symlinks and ensures the correct React version is used.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_51

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "name": "foo",
  "dependencies": {
    "bar": "workspace:1.0.0",
    "react": "16"
  },
  "dependenciesMeta": {
    "bar": {
      "injected": true
    }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Patching Dependencies by Version Ranges in pnpm-workspace.yaml
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to patch dependencies using version ranges in the pnpm-workspace.yaml file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
patchedDependencies:
  foo: patches/foo-1.patch
  foo@^2.0.0: patches/foo-2.patch
  foo@2.1.0: patches/foo-3.patch
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using pnpm patch Command
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the new pnpm patch command to prepare a package for patching. This command creates a temporary directory with the specified package version for modification.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_34

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm patch express@1.0.0
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using @pnpm/lifecycle to run lifecycle hooks in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to import and use the runLifecycleHook and runPostinstallHooks functions from @pnpm/lifecycle. It shows running a specific hook and all install hooks for a target package.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/exec/lifecycle/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import runLifecycleHook, {runPostinstallHooks} from '@pnpm/lifecycle'

const targetPkgRoot = path.resolve('node_modules/target-pkg')
const pkg = require(path.join(targetPkgRoot, 'package.json'))

// Run a specific hook
await runLifecycleHook('preinstall', pkg, {
  pkgId: 'target-pkg/1.0.0',
  pkgRoot: targetPkgRoot,
  rawConfig: {},
  rootModulesDir: path.resolve('node_modules'),
  unsafePerm: true,
})

// Run all install hooks
await runPostinstallHooks({
  pkgId: 'target-pkg/1.0.0',
  pkgRoot: targetPkgRoot,
  rawConfig: {},
  rootModulesDir: path.resolve('node_modules'),
  unsafePerm: true,
})
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Resolving a GitHub Package Using @pnpm/git-resolver (JavaScript)
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use @pnpm/git-resolver's default export to programmatically resolve the metadata and tarball URL for a git-hosted package. The snippet requires @pnpm/git-resolver as a project dependency and demonstrates asynchronous resolution of a package specified via bareSpecifier, outputting the normalized data. Inputs include the bare specifier string, and the output is the resolved package object containing the package id, normalized specifier, and tarball URL. Limitations include the need for Node.js execution and that errors are not explicitly handled in the example.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/resolving/git-resolver/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
'use strict'\nconst createResolveFromNpm = require('@pnpm/git-resolver').default\n\nconst resolveFromNpm = createResolveFromNpm({})\n\nresolveFromNpm({\n  bareSpecifier: 'kevva/is-negative#16fd36fe96106175d02d066171c44e2ff83bc055'\n})\n.then(resolveResult => console.log(JSON.stringify(resolveResult, null, 2)))\n//> {\n//    "id": "github.com/kevva/is-negative/16fd36fe96106175d02d066171c44e2ff83bc055",\n//    "normalizedBareSpecifier": "github:kevva/is-negative#16fd36fe96106175d02d066171c44e2ff83bc055",\n//    "resolution": {\n//      "tarball": "https://codeload.github.com/kevva/is-negative/tar.gz/16fd36fe96106175d02d066171c44e2ff83bc055"\n//    },\n//    "resolvedVia": "git-repository"\n//  }
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining Allowed Build Dependencies in JSON File (JSON)
DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet shows the expected format for the file referenced by `pnpm.onlyBuiltDependenciesFile`. It contains a simple JSON array listing the names of package names (e.g., 'esbuild', '@reflink/reflink') that are permitted to execute build scripts during the pnpm installation process. Any package not listed here will have its build scripts skipped if this configuration is active.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/plugin-commands-installation/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
["esbuild", "@reflink/reflink"]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Allowed Deprecated Versions in package.json
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to configure allowed deprecated versions in the package.json file using the pnpm.allowedDeprecatedVersions field. This allows muting specific deprecation warnings for packages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_39

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "allowedDeprecatedVersions": {
      "request": "*",
      "express": "1"
    }
  }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring supportedArchitectures in package.json for multi-OS/CPU - JSON
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows a more advanced usage of the supportedArchitectures field for pnpm in package.json, defining an array of operating systems (including Windows, macOS, and the system's current OS) and two CPU architectures (x64 and arm64). It is intended for cases where optional dependencies need to be installed for multiple platforms and architectures simultaneously. Dependencies: Requires pnpm 5.0.0 or greater. Key parameters: os and cpu arrays. Inputs: JSON data under the pnpm.supportedArchitectures key in package.json. Outputs: Controls which platform-specific optional dependencies are installed during pnpm install. Limitation: Specified values must be compatible with Node.js naming conventions; over-specification may increase node_modules size.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/patching/plugin-commands-patching/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{\n  \"pnpm\": {\n    \"supportedArchitectures\": {\n      \"os\": [\"win32\", \"darwin\", \"current\"],\n      \"cpu\": [\"x64\", \"arm64\"]\n    }\n  }\n}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using PackageManifest type from @pnpm/types in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to import and use the PackageManifest type from the @pnpm/types package in a TypeScript file. It creates a simple package manifest object with name and version properties.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/packages/types/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { PackageManifest } from '@pnpm/types'

const pkg: PackageManifest = {
  name: 'foo',
  version: '1.0.0',
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Another Package with Different React Version

TITLE: Defining Lockfile Types in TypeScript for PNPM
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines TypeScript interfaces and types for the PNPM lockfile structure. It includes definitions for dependencies, packages, and various lockfile-specific concepts such as integrity, resolution, and dependencies.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/lockfile/types/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: TypeScript
CODE:
```
export interface Lockfile {
  lockfileVersion: number
  packages?: {
    [dependencyPath: string]: Package
  }
  importers?: {
    [importerPath: string]: ProjectSnapshot
  }
  dependencies?: DependenciesField
  devDependencies?: DependenciesField
  optionalDependencies?: DependenciesField
  peerDependencies?: DependenciesField
  overrides?: OverridesField
  pnpmOverrides?: OverridesField
  patchedDependencies?: PatchedDependencies
}

export interface Package {
  name?: string
  version?: string
  id?: string
  resolution?: Resolution
  dependencies?: DependenciesField
  optionalDependencies?: DependenciesField
  devDependencies?: DependenciesField
  peerDependencies?: DependenciesField
  transitivePeerDependencies?: string[]
  peerDependenciesMeta?: {
    [packageName: string]: {
      optional?: boolean
    }
  }
  cpu?: string[]
  os?: string[]
  engines?: {
    [engineName: string]: string
  }
  deprecated?: string
  hasBin?: boolean
  prepare?: boolean
  requiresBuild?: boolean
  integrity?: string
  link?: boolean
  /** Commit hash used to pin Git dependency */
  commit?: string
  preinstalled?: boolean
  bundled?: boolean
}

export interface ProjectSnapshot {
  specifiers?: {
    [depName: string]: string
  }
  dependencies?: DependenciesField
  optionalDependencies?: DependenciesField
  devDependencies?: DependenciesField
  dependenciesMeta?: DependenciesMeta
  peerDependencies?: DependenciesField
  peerDependenciesMeta?: {
    [packageName: string]: {
      optional?: boolean
    }
  }
  overrides?: OverridesField
  pnpmOverrides?: OverridesField
  patchedDependencies?: PatchedDependencies
}

export type Resolution =
  | ResolvedViaGit
  | ResolvedViaTarball
  | ResolvedViaRegistry
  | ResolvedViaDirectory

export interface ResolvedViaGit {
  type: 'git'
  repo: string
  commit: string
}

export interface ResolvedViaTarball {
  type?: 'tarball' // The type field is optional for tarball resolutions
  tarball: string
  integrity?: string
}

export interface ResolvedViaRegistry {
  integrity: string
}

export interface ResolvedViaDirectory {
  type: 'directory'
  directory: string
}

export interface DependenciesMeta {
  [depName: string]: {
    injected?: boolean
    node?: string | boolean
    engine?: string | boolean
    optional?: boolean
  } | {
    [version: string]: {
      injected?: boolean
      node?: string | boolean
      engine?: string | boolean
      optional?: boolean
    }
  }
}

export type DependenciesField = {
  [depName: string]: string
}

export type OverridesField = {
  [selector: string]: string | OverridesField
}

export type PatchedDependencies = {
  [dependencyPath: string]: string
}
```

TITLE: Using readPackage Hook with @pnpm/core in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Example of using the readPackage hook to modify package manifests during installation. This hook allows for customization of dependency information before it's used by @pnpm/core.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/core/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const { installPkgs } = require('@pnpm/core')

installPkgs({
  hooks: {readPackage}
})

function readPackage (pkg) {
  if (pkg.name === 'foo') {
    pkg.dependencies = {
      bar: '^2.0.0',
    }
  }
  return pkg
}
```

TITLE: Illustrating Peer Dependency Resolution File Structure
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example `node_modules/.pnpm` directory structure following the changes in pnpm v32.0.0. It illustrates how peer dependencies with their own peer dependencies (e.g., `card` needs `react`, `react` needs `typescript`) are resolved and laid out. Different project contexts using different versions of the transitive peer dependency (`typescript`) result in distinct dependency paths within the `.pnpm` directory, even for the same versions of the direct dependencies (`card` and `react`), ensuring correct resolution based on the requiring project's dependency graph.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/resolve-dependencies/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
  project1/package.json
  {
    "dependencies": {
      "card": "1.0.0",
      "react": "16.8.0",
      "typescript": "7.0.0"
    }
  }
  project2/package.json
  {
    "dependencies": {
      "card": "1.0.0",
      "react": "16.8.0",
      "typescript": "8.0.0"
    }
  }
  node_modules
    .pnpm
      card@1.0.0(react@16.8.0(typescript@7.0.0))
        node_modules
          card
          react --> ../../react@16.8.0(typescript@7.0.0)/node_modules/react
      react@16.8.0(typescript@7.0.0)
        node_modules
          react
          typescript --> ../../typescript@7.0.0/node_modules/typescript
      typescript@7.0.0
        node_modules
          typescript
      card@1.0.0(react@16.8.0(typescript@8.0.0))
        node_modules
          card
          react --> ../../react@16.8.0(typescript@8.0.0)/node_modules/react
      react@16.8.0(typescript@8.0.0)
        node_modules
          react
          typescript --> ../../typescript@8.0.0/node_modules/typescript
      typescript@8.0.0
        node_modules
          typescript
```

TITLE: Implementing a pnpm Resolver Using Base Types - TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides a template for implementing a pnpm-compatible resolver using types from @pnpm/resolver-base. It imports the ResolveOptions, ResolveResult, and WantedDependency types and then defines an asynchronous function, testResolver, that receives a wanted dependency and resolve options, returning a promise resolving to a ResolveResult. Key function parameters include the dependency descriptor and resolver options; the function is expected to return essential resolution details such as id, resolution, and package object. This template requires that @pnpm/resolver-base is installed as a dependency. Inputs are a WantedDependency object and ResolveOptions, output is a ResolveResult. The internal implementation (not shown) should resolve a package using the provided types.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/resolving/resolver-base/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
import {
  ResolveOptions,
  ResolveResult,
  WantedDependency,
} from '@pnpm/resolver-base'

export async function testResolver (
  wantedDependency: WantedDependency,
  opts: ResolveOptions,
): Promise<ResolveResult> {
  // ...
  return {
    id,
    resolution,
    package,
    latest,
    normalizedBareSpecifier,
  }
}
```

TITLE: Using @pnpm/dependency-path Utility Functions
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the usage of various utility functions provided by the dependency-path package for handling package paths, including path resolution, conversion between absolute and relative paths, and parsing package references.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/packages/dependency-path/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
const dependencyPath = require('@pnpm/dependency-path')

const registry = 'https://registry.npmjs.org/'

console.log(dependencyPath.isAbsolute('/foo/1.0.0'))
//> false

// it is confusing currently because relative starts with /.
// It will be changed in the future to vice versa
console.log(dependencyPath.resolve(registry, '/foo/1.0.0'))
//> registry.npmjs.org/foo/1.0.0

console.log(dependencyPath.relative(registry, 'registry.npmjs.org/foo/1.0.0'))
//> /foo/1.0.0

console.log(dependencyPath.refToAbsolute('1.0.1', 'foo', registry))
//> registry.npmjs.org/foo/1.0.1

console.log(dependencyPath.refToAbsolute('github.com/foo/bar/twe0jger043t0ew', 'foo', registry))
//> github.com/foo/bar/twe0jger043t0ew

console.log(dependencyPath.refToRelative('1.0.1', 'foo', registry))
//> /foo/1.0.1

console.log(dependencyPath.parse('/foo/2.0.0'))
//> { isAbsolute: false, name: 'foo', version: '2.0.0' }
```

```

It maps the JSR package to an npm alias using the `npm:` prefix and a specific naming convention (`@jsr/scope__name@version`).

TITLE: Configuring Multiple Architectures for Optional Dependencies (pnpm, JSON)
DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet demonstrates a pnpm configuration that specifies support for Windows, macOS, and the current system's architecture, including both x64 and arm64 CPUs. It is added to the "pnpm" field in package.json and is supported from pnpm version 24.1.0 onwards. The configuration enables broader architectural support for optional dependencies, and "current" in the "os" field automatically includes the operating system of the installer.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/package-requester/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:

{
  "pnpm": {
    "supportedArchitectures": {
      "os": ["win32", "darwin", "current"],
      "cpu": ["x64", "arm64"]
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Managing Global Package Installation using Bash and .npmrc
DESCRIPTION: Updates global installation behavior in v14.0.0. `pnpm install -g pkg` now installs to a predefined location controlled by the `PNPM_HOME` environment variable or the `global-bin-dir` setting in `.npmrc`. pnpm no longer attempts to modify global Node.js or npm folders.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/config/config/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_21

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# Install a package globally (installs to PNPM_HOME or global-bin-dir)
pnpm install -g <package-name>

# Set global bin directory via environment variable
export PNPM_HOME=/path/to/global/bin
```

LANGUAGE: .npmrc
CODE:
```
# Set global bin directory via .npmrc
global-bin-dir = /path/to/global/bin
```

TITLE: Adding Virtual Store Directory Length Setting in pnpm
DESCRIPTION: Adds a new setting 'virtual-store-dir-max-length' to modify the maximum allowed length of directories inside node_modules/.pnpm. This is useful on Windows to avoid path length limitations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/patching/plugin-commands-patching/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Minor Changes

- 9719a42: New setting called `virtual-store-dir-max-length` added to modify the maximum allowed length of the directories inside `node_modules/.pnpm`. The default length is set to 120 characters. This setting is particularly useful on Windows, where there is a limit to the maximum length of a file path [#7355](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/issues/7355).
```

TITLE: Reading and Writing node_modules Metadata using @pnpm/modules-yaml (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates importing the read and write functions from the @pnpm/modules-yaml package, and using them to persist and retrieve the .modules.yaml configuration file within a node_modules directory. Requires the @pnpm/modules-yaml dependency to be installed. The write function takes a target directory path and a ModulesObject with keys like hoistedAliases, layoutVersion, packageManager, pendingBuilds, shamefullyFlatten, skipped, and storeDir, writing this data to a YAML file; read will asynchronously load this file back as a JavaScript object. Both functions return Promises: write resolves with void, and read resolves with the loaded configuration object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/modules-yaml/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import {write, read} from '@pnpm/modules-yaml'

await write('node_modules', {
  hoistedAliases: {},
  layoutVersion: 1,
  packageManager: 'pnpm@1.0.0',
  pendingBuilds: [],
  shamefullyFlatten: false,
  skipped: [],
  storeDir: '/home/user/.pnpm-store',
})

const modulesYaml = await read(`node_modules`)
```

  .pnpm

  node_modules

project2
  node_modules

```

import { PnpmError } from '@pnpm/error'

    throw new PnpmError('THE_ERROR_CODE', 'The error message')
} catch (err: any) { // eslint-disable-line
    console.log(err.code)
    //> ERR_PNPM_THE_ERROR_CODE

    //> The error message
}

TITLE: Configuring Node.js Download Mirrors in .npmrc
DESCRIPTION: Introduces dynamic `node-mirror:<releaseDir>` settings in v13.7.0. The value of this setting is used as the base URL for downloading Node.js when `use-node-version` is specified. The specific `<releaseDir>` (e.g., 'release', 'nightly') used depends on the `use-node-version` value. Defaults to `https://nodejs.org/download/<releaseDir>/`.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/config/config/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_27

LANGUAGE: .npmrc
CODE:
```
# Specify the Node.js version to use
use-node-version = 18.12.0

# Specify a mirror for stable 'release' versions
node-mirror:release = https://mymirror.example.com/node/release/

# Specify a mirror for 'nightly' versions
# use-node-version = nightly
# node-mirror:nightly = https://mymirror.example.com/node/nightly/
```

  }
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Non-Overlapping Version Ranges for Patching in YAML
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to properly configure non-overlapping version ranges when patching dependencies in pnpm. It demonstrates how to specialize a sub-range while excluding it from more general patches.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/patching/types/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
# pnpm-workspace.yaml
patchedDependencies:
  # the specialized sub range
  'foo@2.2.0-2.8.0': patches/foo.2.2.0-2.8.0.patch
  # the more general patch, excluding the sub range above
  'foo@>=2.0.0 <2.2.0 || >2.8.0': 'patches/foo.gte2.patch
```

TITLE: Updating pnpm version 9.0.0 in Markdown
DESCRIPTION: Details major changes for pnpm version 9.0.0, including updates to default behaviors, removal of Node.js 14 support, and changes to lockfile handling.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/core/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
## 9.0.0

### Major Changes

- 47e45d717: `auto-install-peers` is `true` by default.
- 47e45d717: `save-workspace-protocol` is `rolling` by default.
- 54591c686: `dedupe-peer-dependents` is `true` by default.
- 158d8cf22: `useLockfileV6` field is deleted. Lockfile v5 cannot be written anymore, only transformed to the new format.
- eceaa8b8b: Node.js 14 support dropped.
- 8e35c21d1: Use lockfile v6 by default.
- 47e45d717: `resolve-peers-from-workspace-root` is `true` by default.
- 47e45d717: `publishConfig.linkDirectory` is `true` by default.
- 113f0ae26: `resolution-mode` is `lowest-direct` by default.
- 47e45d717: Direct dependencies are deduped. So if the same dependency is both in a project and in the workspace root, then it is only linked to the workspace root.

### Patch Changes

- 2a2032810: Don't write the `pnpm-lock.yaml` file if it has no changes and `pnpm install --frozen-lockfile` was executed [#6158](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/issues/6158).
- Updated dependencies [1d105e7fc]
- Updated dependencies [c92936158]
- Updated dependencies [2a2032810]

- Updated dependencies [158d8cf22]
- Updated dependencies [0a8b48f04]
- Updated dependencies [ca8f51e60]
- Updated dependencies [eceaa8b8b]
- Updated dependencies [0e26acb0f]
- Updated dependencies [634d6874b]
- Updated dependencies [b4f26e41a]
- Updated dependencies [cfb6bb3bf]
- Updated dependencies [417c8ac59]
  - @pnpm/resolve-dependencies@31.0.0
  - @pnpm/lockfile-utils@6.0.0
  - @pnpm/get-context@9.0.0
  - @pnpm/hooks.read-package-hook@3.0.0
  - @pnpm/lockfile-file@8.0.0
  - @pnpm/dependency-path@2.0.0
  - @pnpm/read-project-manifest@5.0.0
  - @pnpm/parse-wanted-dependency@5.0.0
  - @pnpm/which-version-is-pinned@5.0.0
  - @pnpm/read-package-json@8.0.0
  - @pnpm/pkg-manager.direct-dep-linker@2.0.0
  - @pnpm/package-requester@21.0.0

TITLE: Illustrating pnpm Node Modules Structure Without Peer Deduplication
DESCRIPTION: This example shows the resulting `node_modules` layout in a pnpm workspace when `dedupe-peer-dependents` is false (the default). It demonstrates how two separate instances of `webpack` are stored in the `.pnpm` virtual store because `project2` includes `esbuild` (an optional peer dependency of `webpack`), while `project1` does not, preventing them from sharing the same `webpack` instance.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/config/config/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
node_modules
  .pnpm
    webpack@1.0.0_esbuild@1.0.0
    webpack@1.0.0
project1
  node_modules
    webpack -> ../../node_modules/.pnpm/webpack@1.0.0/node_modules/webpack
project2
  node_modules
    webpack -> ../../node_modules/.pnpm/webpack@1.0.0_esbuild@1.0.0/node_modules/webpack
    esbuild
```

TITLE: Script Path Settings - PNPM v12.1.0
DESCRIPTION: Introduces new scriptsPrependNodePath setting with three options for handling node executable paths in scripts
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/exec/lifecycle/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Minor Changes
- 002778559: New setting added: `scriptsPrependNodePath`. This setting can be `true`, `false`, or `warn-only`.
  When `true`, the path to the `node` executable with which pnpm executed is prepended to the `PATH` of the scripts.
  When `warn-only`, pnpm will print a warning if the scripts run with a `node` binary that differs from the `node` binary executing the pnpm CLI.
```

TITLE: Configuring supportedArchitectures in package.json for Windows x64 - JSON
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to configure the supportedArchitectures option within the pnpm field in package.json to install optional dependencies for the Windows x64 platform. It specifies the target operating system (os: ["win32"]) and CPU architecture (cpu: ["x64"]). This allows pnpm to install any optional dependencies required for that specific platform, regardless of the host's system configuration. Dependencies: Used in conjunction with pnpm 5.0.0+ that supports the supportedArchitectures field. Inputs: A JSON config placed under the pnpm key in package.json. Outputs: Determines which platform dependencies are installed on pnpm install. Limitations: Target OS and CPU values must match valid Node.js platform and architecture names.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/patching/plugin-commands-patching/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```

```

DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript snippet shows how to import the `getBinsFromPkg` function from the `@pnpm/package-bins` library. The function returns a Promise that resolves to an array of objects, where each object contains the `name` of a binary command and its corresponding file `path`.

```

TITLE: Resolving an npm Package with @pnpm/npm-resolver - JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet initializes the @pnpm/npm-resolver, configuring it to point to a custom store and the default npm registry. It then uses the created resolver instance to resolve a package (specified by alias and version), retrieves detailed metadata and resolution information, and logs the result as formatted JSON. Dependencies include '@pnpm/npm-resolver' for resolution, Node.js for execution, and network access to the npm registry unless offline mode is enabled. The function accepts resolver options like 'alias' and 'bareSpecifier', and outputs package information with version, dependencies, and tarball details.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/resolving/npm-resolver/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
```
'use strict'\nconst createResolveFromNpm = require('@pnpm/npm-resolver').default\n\nconst resolveFromNpm = createResolveFromNpm({\n  store: '.store',\n  offline: false,\n  rawConfig: {\n    registry: 'https://registry.npmjs.org/',\n  },\n})\n\nresolveFromNpm({alias: 'is-positive', bareSpecifier: '1.0.0'}, {\n  registry: 'https://registry.npmjs.org/',\n})\n.then(resolveResult => console.log(JSON.stringify(resolveResult, null, 2)))\n//> {\n//    "id": "registry.npmjs.org/is-positive/1.0.0",\n//    "latest": "3.1.0",\n//    "package": {\n//      "name": "is-positive",\n//      "version": "1.0.0",\n//      "devDependencies": {\n//        "ava": "^0.0.4"\n//      },\n//      "_hasShrinkwrap": false,\n//      "directories": {},\n//      "dist": {\n//        "shasum": "88009856b64a2f1eb7d8bb0179418424ae0452cb",\n//        "tarball": "https://registry.npmjs.org/is-positive/-/is-positive-1.0.0.tgz"\n//      },\n//      "engines": {\n//        "node": ">=0.10.0"\n//      }\n//    },\n//    "resolution": {\n//      "integrity": "sha1-iACYVrZKLx632LsBeUGEJK4EUss=",\n//      "registry": "https://registry.npmjs.org/",\n//      "tarball": "https://registry.npmjs.org/is-positive/-/is-positive-1.0.0.tgz"\n//    },\n//    "resolvedVia": "npm-registry"\n//  }
```

TITLE: Major Change Documentation for Version 2.0.0
DESCRIPTION: Documents a significant change in how index files are stored in the store, using both content hash and package identifier to handle identical content published under different package names or versions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/__utils__/assert-store/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
Some registries allow identical content to be published under different package names or versions. To accommodate this, index files in the store are now stored using both the content hash and package identifier.

This approach ensures that we can:
1. Validate that the integrity in the lockfile corresponds to the correct package,
   which might not be the case after a poorly resolved Git conflict.
2. Allow the same content to be referenced by different packages or different versions of the same package.

Related PR: [#8510](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/pull/8510)
Related issue: [#8204](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/issues/8204)
```

This example includes Windows, macOS, the current system, and both x64 and arm64 CPUs. Dependencies rely on a pnpm version supporting this schema; main configuration keys mirror the Node.js os and cpu platform flags.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/workspace/filter-workspace-packages/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{\n  \"pnpm\": {\n    \"supportedArchitectures\": {\n      \"os\": [\"win32\", \"darwin\", \"current\"],\n      \"cpu\": [\"x64\", \"arm64\"]\n    }\n  }\n}
```

TITLE: Configuring pnpm `supportedArchitectures` for Multiple OS/CPU Combinations
DESCRIPTION: This JSON example shows how to configure the `pnpm.supportedArchitectures` setting in `package.json` (for pnpm v8.1.0+) to install optional dependencies for multiple platforms. It targets Windows (`win32`), macOS (`darwin`), and the operating system of the machine running the install (`current`), along with both x64 and arm64 CPU architectures. This allows broader support for optional dependencies across different environments.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/store/plugin-commands-store/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "supportedArchitectures": {
      "os": ["win32", "darwin", "current"],
      "cpu": ["x64", "arm64"]
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Creating a Package Dependency Graph with @pnpm/workspace.pkgs-graph
DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to use the createPkgsGraph function to generate a dependency graph from an array of packages. The graph represents the dependency relationships between packages in a workspace.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/workspace/pkgs-graph/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import createPkgsGraph from 'pkgs-graph'

const {graph} = createPkgsGraph([
  {
    dir: '/home/zkochan/src/foo',
    manifest: {
      name: 'foo',
      version: '1.0.0',
      dependencies: {
        bar: '^1.0.0',
      },
    },
  },
  {
    dir: '/home/zkochan/src/bar',
    manifest: {
      name: 'bar',
      version: '1.1.0',
    },
  }
])

console.log(graph)
//> {
//    '/home/zkochan/src/foo': {
//      dependencies: ['/home/zkochan/src/bar'],
//      manifest: {
//        name: 'foo',
//        version: '1.0.0',
//        dependencies: {
//          bar: '^1.0.0',
//        },
//      },
//    },
//    '/home/zkochan/src/bar': {
//      dependencies: [],
//      manifest: {
//        name: 'bar',
//        version: '1.1.0',
//      },
//    },
//  }
```

TITLE: Major Version Changes Documentation
DESCRIPTION: Documents major breaking changes in version 2.0.0 including virtual store directory structure changes, content-addressable filesystem implementation, and package index file format updates
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/store/plugin-commands-store/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Major Changes

- b5f66c0f2: Reduce the number of directories in the virtual store directory. Don't create a subdirectory for the package version. Append the package version to the package name directory.
- 9596774f2: Store the package index files in the CAFS to reduce directory nesting.
- da091c711: Remove state from store. The store should not store the information about what projects on the computer use what dependencies.
- 802d145fc: Remove `independent-leaves` support.
- b6a82072e: Using a content-addressable filesystem for storing packages.
- 471149e66: Change the format of the package index file. Move all the files info into a "files" property.
- 9fbb74ecb: The structure of virtual store directory changed. No subdirectory created with the registry name.
```

TITLE: Configuring package.json for pnpm macOS ARM64 Support
DESCRIPTION: Defines the package configuration for @pnpm/macos-arm64, including version, description, dependencies, and build scripts. It specifies the binary file location and sets up npm configuration for the package.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pnpm/artifacts/macos-arm64/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "name": "@pnpm/macos-arm64",
  "version": "8.6.0",
  "description": "pnpm's macOS ARM64 binary",
  "repository": "https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm.git",
  "homepage": "https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/packages/packages/macos-arm64#readme",
  "license": "MIT",
  "scripts": {
    "publish:docs": "true"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@pnpm/macos-arm64-libpnpm-cli": "8.6.0"
  },
  "main": "node_modules/.pnpm/@pnpm+macos-arm64-libpnpm-cli@8.6.0/node_modules/@pnpm/macos-arm64-libpnpm-cli/package/dist/pnpm.cjs",
  "bin": {
    "pnpm": "node_modules/.pnpm/@pnpm+macos-arm64-libpnpm-cli@8.6.0/node_modules/@pnpm/macos-arm64-libpnpm-cli/package/bin/pnpm.cjs",
    "pnpx": "node_modules/.pnpm/@pnpm+macos-arm64-libpnpm-cli@8.6.0/node_modules/@pnpm/macos-arm64-libpnpm-cli/package/bin/pnpx.cjs"
  },
  "os": [
    "darwin"
  ],
  "cpu": [
    "arm64"
  ],
  "files": [
    "npm-shrinkwrap.json"
  ],
  "publishConfig": {
    "bin": {
      "pnpm": "package/bin/pnpm.cjs",
      "pnpx": "package/bin/pnpx.cjs"
    },
    "main": "package/dist/pnpm.cjs"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=16.14"
  }
}
```

TITLE: PNPM Version 10.2.0 Lock File Settings Changes
DESCRIPTION: Documents major changes to lockfile format including new settings field and version bump from v6.0 to v6.1
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/core/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Minor Changes

- 9c4ae87bd: Some settings influence the structure of the lockfile, so we cannot reuse the lockfile if those settings change. As a result, we need to store such settings in the lockfile. This way we will know with which settings the lockfile has been created.

  A new field will now be present in the lockfile: `settings`. It will store the values of two settings: `autoInstallPeers` and `excludeLinksFromLockfile`. If someone tries to perform a `frozen-lockfile` installation and their active settings don't match the ones in the lockfile, then an error message will be thrown.

  The lockfile format version is bumped from v6.0 to v6.1.
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/modules-mounter/daemon/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Minor Changes
- d433cb9: Some registries allow identical content to be published under different package names or versions. To accommodate this, index files in the store are now stored using both the content hash and package identifier.
```

TITLE: Markdown Changelog Entry for Version 6.0.0
DESCRIPTION: Documentation of breaking changes and new features in version 6.0.0, including dropping Node.js v16 support and adding Git subdirectory installation capability.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/exec/prepare-package/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Major Changes
- 43cdd87: Node.js v16 support dropped. Use at least Node.js v18.12.

### Minor Changes
- b13d2dc: It is now possible to install only a subdirectory from a Git repository.

  For example, `pnpm add github:user/repo#path:packages/foo` will add a dependency from the `packages/foo` subdirectory.

  This new parameter may be combined with other supported parameters separated by `&`. For instance, the next command will install the same package from the `dev` branch: `pnpm add github:user/repo#dev&path:packages/bar`.

  Related issue: [#4765](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/issues/4765).
  Related PR: [#7487](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/pull/7487).
```

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```

    [0, [1]],
    [1, [2]],
    [2, [3]],
    [3, [0]],
  ]), [0, 1, 2, 3])).toStrictEqual(
    {
      safe: false,
      chunks: [[0, 1, 2, 3]],
      cycles: [[0, 1, 2, 3]],
    }
  )
```

TITLE: Using TestIpcServer in a Test Case
DESCRIPTION: Example of how to use the TestIpcServer in a test to capture and verify script output. The server creates an IPC channel that scripts can send messages to, which are then collected for test assertions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/__utils__/test-ipc-server/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { prepare } from '@pnpm/prepare'
import { createTestIpcServer } from '@pnpm/test-ipc-server'

test('example test', async () => {
  await using server = await createTestIpcServer()
  prepare({
    scripts: {
      build: server.sendLineScript('this is a built script that should run'),
    },
  })

  await execa('node', [pnpmBin, 'run', 'build'])

  expect(server.getLines()).toStrictEqual(['this is a built script that should run'])
})
```

TITLE: Using @pnpm/assert-project in TypeScript tests
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the assertProject function from @pnpm/assert-project in a TypeScript test file. It shows importing the necessary modules, setting up a test, and using the assertProject function to check for the presence of a package in the project's node_modules.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/__utils__/assert-project/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import test = require('tape')
import { assertProject } from '@pnpm/assert-project'

test('...', async t => {
  // ...
  const project = assertProject(t, pathToProject)

  project.has('foo')
  // Test fails if project has no foo in node_modules
})
```

TITLE: Defining Constants for pnpm Package Manager in Markdown
DESCRIPTION: This markdown document outlines version changes and updates to various constants used in the pnpm package manager. It includes changes to lockfile versions, store layouts, and other key constants.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/packages/constants/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
# @pnpm/constants

## 1001.1.0

### Minor Changes

- 9a44e6c: `pnpm deploy` should inherit the `pnpm` object from the root `package.json` [#8991](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/pull/8991).

## 1001.0.0

### Major Changes

- d2e83b0: Metadata directory version bumped to force fresh cache after we shipped a fix to the metadata write function. This change is backward compatible as install doesn't require a metadata cache.
- a76da0c: Removed lockfile conversion from v6 to v9. If you need to convert lockfile v6 to v9, use pnpm CLI v9.

## 10.0.0

### Major Changes

- 8108680: Changed the format of the side-effects cache key.
- c4f5231: Store version bumped to v10. The new store layout has a different directory called "index" for storing the package content mappings. Previously these files were stored in the same directory where the package contents are (in "files"). The new store has also a new format for storing the mappings for side-effects cache.

### Minor Changes

- 19d5b51: Add `MANIFEST_BASE_NAMES`

## 9.0.0

### Major Changes

- 83681da: Keep `libc` field in `clearMeta`.

## 8.0.0

### Major Changes

- 43cdd87: Node.js v16 support dropped. Use at least Node.js v18.12.
- d381a60: Support for lockfile v5 is dropped. Use pnpm v8 to convert lockfile v5 to lockfile v6 [#7470](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/pull/7470).

### Minor Changes

- c692f80: Bump lockfile to v6.1

## 7.1.1

### Patch Changes

- 302ebffc5: Change lockfile version back to 6.0 as previous versions of pnpm fail to parse the version correctly.

## 7.1.0

### Minor Changes

- 9c4ae87bd: Bump lockfile v6 version to v6.1.

## 7.0.0

### Major Changes

- eceaa8b8b: Node.js 14 support dropped.

## 6.2.0

### Minor Changes

- 3ebce5db7: Exported a constant for the new lockfile format version: `LOCKFILE_FORMAT_V6`.

## 6.1.0

### Minor Changes

- 1267e4eff: Lockfile version bumped to 5.4

## 6.0.0

### Major Changes

- 542014839: Node.js 12 is not supported.

## 5.0.0

### Major Changes

- 6871d74b2: Bump lockfile version to 5.3.
- 97b986fbc: Node.js 10 support is dropped. At least Node.js 12.17 is required for the package to work.
- f2bb5cbeb: Bump layout version to 5.

## 4.1.0

### Minor Changes

- fcdad632f: Bump lockfile version to 5.2

## 4.0.0

### Major Changes

- b5f66c0f2: Reduce the number of directories in the virtual store directory. Don't create a subdirectory for the package version. Append the package version to the package name directory.
- ca9f50844: Bump lockfile version to 5.2.
- 4f5801b1c: Changing lockfile version back to 5.1

## 4.0.0-alpha.1

### Major Changes

- ca9f50844: Bump lockfile version to 5.2.

## 4.0.0-alpha.0

### Major Changes

- b5f66c0f2: Reduce the number of directories in the virtual store directory. Don't create a subdirectory for the package version. Append the package version to the package name directory.
```

TITLE: Version 1000.3.0 Minor Changes
DESCRIPTION: Implements feature changes around patch handling, including renaming allowNonAppliedPatches to allowUnusedPatches and adding ignorePatchFailures configuration
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/exec/build-modules/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
## 1000.3.0

### Minor Changes

- 5f7be64: Rename `pnpm.allowNonAppliedPatches` to `pnpm.allowUnusedPatches`. The old name is still supported but it would print a deprecation warning message.
- 5f7be64: Add `pnpm.ignorePatchFailures` to manage whether pnpm would ignore patch application failures.

  If `ignorePatchFailures` is not set, pnpm would throw an error when patches with exact versions or version ranges fail to apply, and it would ignore failures from name-only patches.

  If `ignorePatchFailures` is explicitly set to `false`, pnpm would throw an error when any type of patch fails to apply.

  If `ignorePatchFailures` is explicitly set to `true`, pnpm would print a warning when any type of patch fails to apply.
```

TITLE: Using Assert Store for Testing PNPM Stores
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to use assertStore utility with tape testing framework to verify package presence in a PNPM store. Demonstrates checking if a specific package version exists in the store.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/__utils__/assert-store/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import test = require('tape')
import { assertStore } from '@pnpm/assert-store'

test('...', async t => {
  // ...
  const store = assertStore(t, pathToStore, encodedRegistryName)

  await store.storeHas('is-positive', '3.1.0')
  // Test fails if pnpm store does not have this package
})
```

TITLE: Using @pnpm/link-bins in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use the linkBins and linkBinsOfPackages functions from the @pnpm/link-bins package. It shows linking bins for all packages and for specific packages with custom warning handling.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/pkg-manager/link-bins/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import linkBins, {linkBinsOfPackages} from '@pnpm/link-bins'

function warn (msg) { console.warn(msg) }

await linkBins('node_modules', 'node_modules/.bin', {warn})

const packages = [{manifest: packageJson, location: pathToPackage}]
await linkBinsOfPackages(packages, 'node_modules/.bin', {warn})
```

TITLE: Transformed Dependency for npm-Compatible Publishing - JSON
DESCRIPTION: This JSON example represents how the @foo/bar dependency, initially added as a JSR package, is transformed when publishing to make it compatible with npm, Yarn, and older pnpm versions. The value is rewritten as npm:@jsr/foo__bar@^0.1.2. Inputs are typically handled by pnpm during the publish phase, and manual transformation is unnecessary.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/resolving/default-resolver/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{\n  \"dependencies\": {\n    \"@foo/bar\": \"npm:@jsr/foo__bar@^0.1.2\"\n  }\n}
```

TITLE: Feature Update - packageManager Field Addition
DESCRIPTION: Notable feature addition in version 1000.1.0 that adds packageManager field to package.json during pnpm init and allows configuring this behavior through init-package-manager setting.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/packages/plugin-commands-init/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
### Minor Changes

- 49cc167: Add the `init-package-manager` configuration. When the value is set to `false`, `pnpm init` won't add the `packageManager` field to the initialized `package.json` file [#9087](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/pull/9087).
- 483384a: `pnpm init` command adds a `packageManager` field with the current version of pnpm CLI [#9069](https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/pull/9069).
```

TITLE: Configuring Supported Architectures for Windows x64 in pnpm (JSON)
DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet demonstrates how to configure the `supportedArchitectures` field within the `pnpm` object in `package.json` as introduced in version 1.1.0. It specifies that optional dependencies should be installed for the Windows (win32) operating system and the x64 CPU architecture.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/workspace/find-packages/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "pnpm": {
    "supportedArchitectures": {
      "os": ["win32"],
      "cpu": ["x64"]
    }
  }
}
```

### Minor Changes

### Major Changes

TITLE: Configuring Registry-Scoped SSL Settings in pnpm (INI)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to configure registry-specific SSL settings (certificate file, key file, and CA file) in pnpm's configuration. These settings allow for custom SSL configurations for different private or internal registries. The example shows the format using comments as placeholders for actual registry URLs and file paths.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/releasing/plugin-commands-publishing/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: ini
CODE:
```
//registry.mycomp.com/:certfile=server-cert.pem
//registry.mycomp.com/:keyfile=server-key.pem

TITLE: Configuring supportedArchitectures in pnpm using JSON
DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet demonstrates how to specify optional dependency installation for a specific OS (Windows) and CPU architecture (x64) in pnpm. This configuration should be added under the "pnpm" field in a project's package.json file. The expected input is the JSON configuration itself, which instructs pnpm to consider win32 OS and x64 CPU as supported for optional dependencies; the output is pnpm behavior adapted for these targets during install. No external dependencies or constraints exist beyond having a compatible pnpm version.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/releasing/plugin-commands-publishing/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```

    "supportedArchitectures": {
      "os": ["win32"],
      "cpu": ["x64"]
    }
  }
}
```

TITLE: Resolving a Local Package using @pnpm/local-resolver (JavaScript)
DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet demonstrates how to use the `resolveFromLocal` function from the `@pnpm/local-resolver` package. It imports the function, calls it with a resolution request object specifying a relative path (`bareSpecifier`) and a base directory (`prefix`), and logs the resulting resolution object containing package details and metadata. This requires the `@pnpm/local-resolver` package to be installed and a Node.js environment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/resolving/local-resolver/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
'use strict'
const resolveFromLocal = require('@pnpm/local-resolver').default

resolveFromLocal({bareSpecifier: './example-package'}, {prefix: process.cwd()})
  .then(resolveResult => console.log(resolveResult))
//> { id: 'link:example-package',
//    normalizedBareSpecifier: 'link:example-package',
//    package:
//     { name: 'foo',
//       version: '1.0.0',
//       readme: '# foo\n',
//       readmeFilename: 'README.md',
//       description: '',
//       _id: 'foo@1.0.0' },
//    resolution: { directory: 'example-package', type: 'directory' }
//    resolvedVia: 'local-filesystem' }
```

TITLE: Configuring Automatic Syncing of Injected Workspace Dependencies in pnpm using .npmrc (ini)
DESCRIPTION: This configuration snippet, placed in a `.npmrc` file at the workspace root, instructs pnpm to automatically sync injected workspace dependencies after specific build scripts complete. In this example, syncing occurs after the `compile` script finishes, ensuring packages depending on the built package receive the updated files. This feature requires a compatible pnpm version (introduced around version `1000.0.0` of this package) and a workspace setup.
SOURCE: https://github.com/pnpm/pnpm/blob/main/workspace/injected-deps-syncer/CHANGELOG.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: ini
CODE:
```
sync-injected-deps-after-scripts[]=compile
```

### Major Changes

### Patch Changes

- 4b97f1f07: Don't use await in loops.

## 6.0.0

### Major Changes

- eceaa8b8b: Node.js 14 support dropped.

## 5.0.0

### Major Changes

- f884689e0: Require `@pnpm/logger` v5.

## 4.0.0

### Major Changes

- 542014839: Node.js 12 is not supported.

## 3.0.1

### Patch Changes

- 71aab049d: Fix EMFILE error.

## 3.0.0

### Major Changes

- 97b986fbc: Node.js 10 support is dropped. At least Node.js 12.17 is required for the package to work.

## 2.0.3

### Patch Changes

- 24af41f20: Ignore files in node_modules.

## 2.0.2

### Patch Changes

- a2ef8084f: Use the same versions of dependencies across the pnpm monorepo.

## 2.0.2
```
